data.text:
There are two items in this world that humans hate wasting. Time and Money. With two words, anyone can be drawn into a product, action, or idea. “Free Kittens” can mean more than just a new companion to adults. For some, it means three things; a cat, no money, and no waiting. In Roy Peter Clark’s book, How to Write Short: Word Craft for Fast Times, he dedicates and entire chapter to slogans and sales. By analyzing what needs to be said, conveying that to customers, and constructing the output, Roy Peter Clark shows us that all slogans are works of short writing. Slogans speak for the product where the company cannot. No matter the media it appears from, it has a lasting impression on everyone.

For example, when Burger King came out with “Have It Your Way”, as much as it was a marketing scheme to draw people to the restaurant, it was a jab at other places for their exclusion to this idea. There is a lot of angst that is behind some of his arguments that could have been let loose. The opinions of the people are the reason why slogans succeed or fail. Roy Peter Clark is an articulate author who has the same outlook on writing as I do: “Get it done now and fast”. However, he missed a huge opportunity to talk about why we are marketed to. Personally, not being able to live a life without being sold to on a daily basis is extremely annoying. Because his idea of slogans was very one sided, the text was dry and sparse from original ideas. Roy Peter Clark is a successful author with over seventeen books published and selling all over the country. In his book, How to Write Short: Word Craft for Fast Times, he captures the essence of slogans, their purpose, and the positivity of their nature. Even though both sides of every story (or slogan) should be known, Clark stays firm in his facts and his stance. Slogans are everywhere, even in your closet.
